concern:
I was very confused about what to major in after high school. But i searched a bit about computer science, it courses from what my future uni offers, asked for advice around, listened to people from yt IN cs and its jobs prospects, plus i started to like the field but have no experience in coding, so thats what i choseâ€¦ 
   Did i make a good choice?


(I have good grades)
(I wont say i have practice in every maths courses cs offers but i like maths so thats that thing out of the way)
(Also please advice if I wont lose job opportunities as a Women in cs)

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome! I'm here to listen and support you in any way I can. Please feel free to share whatever's on your mindâ€”I'm all ears and ready to help. ðŸ˜Š
Thanks for being here! Iâ€™ve been kinda stressing about whether I made the right call picking computer science as my major, especially since Iâ€™m new to coding and just hoping it works out.

You seem to be feeling quite uncertain about your major choice, and that's completely understandable, especially since you're just starting out in the field. It's natural to feel overwhelmed when diving into something new, and I'm here to listen and help you work through these thoughts.

Yeah, exactly, I just donâ€™t know if Iâ€™m setting myself up for something I can actually handle. Iâ€™m excited about computer science, but the whole no-coding-experience thing is making me second-guess myself a bit.

It sounds like you're caught between the excitement of exploring a new field and the uncertainty that comes with not having prior experience. That can be a tough place to be in, especially when you're trying to make a decision that feels right for you. Can you tell me more about what's making you question your choice?

Honestly, itâ€™s mostly just the fear of not being good enough since Iâ€™m starting from scratch with coding. I also worry if Iâ€™ll fit into the field long-term, ya know, with all the unknowns about job stuff and being a woman in tech.

It's understandable that those fears are lingering in your mind, especially with the added layer of being a woman in tech. Can you think of a time when you faced a similar challenge, and how you managed to overcome it?

I guess, yeah, like when I first started high school and had to adjust to harder classes, I felt pretty out of my depth. I just kept at it, asked for help when I needed it, and eventually got the hang of things, so maybe I can do that here too.

That sounds like a great example of your resilience and ability to adapt. It's really encouraging to hear how you managed to overcome those challenges in high school, and it's possible that you can apply those same skills to this new challenge in computer science.
Thanks, thatâ€™s kinda reassuring to hear. I just hope I can keep pushing through like I did back then, even if this feels like a whole different beast with coding and all.

Itâ€™s natural to feel apprehensive about tackling something new and unfamiliar, especially when it's as complex as coding. Yet, it sounds like you've already proven to yourself that you're capable of overcoming challenges and adapting to new situations. Perhaps you can draw on that experience and remind yourself that it's okay to take things one step at a time, seeking help when needed, just as you did in high school.

Yeah, I get that taking it step by step is probably the way to go, even if it feels overwhelming right now. Iâ€™m just gonna have to keep reminding myself that Iâ€™ve handled tough stuff before and can do it again with this.

It's really great to hear that you're drawing on your past experiences to build confidence in your ability to handle this new challenge. Can we think about some specific steps you could take to apply those same strategies you used in high school to your current situation with coding?

Yeah, I think thatâ€™d be helpful to figure out some concrete steps. Like, maybe I could start by finding some beginner coding tutorials online or joining a study group at uni to get help and not feel so alone in this.

That's a solid plan to start with, and I like that you're thinking about ways to connect with others for support. What do you think would be the most helpful first step for you - diving into those tutorials or reaching out to join a study group?

Honestly, I think starting with some beginner tutorials online might be the best first step for me. It feels less intimidating than jumping into a group right away, and I can kinda get a feel for coding on my own before asking for help or joining others.

That makes sense, and itâ€™s great that youâ€™re thinking about what will make you feel most comfortable as you start. Now that youâ€™ve decided on online tutorials, letâ€™s brainstorm some specific options and maybe even set a small goal for the first few daysâ€”like dedicating 20 minutes a day to exploring one or two beginner-friendly platforms. What do you think?

Yeah, that sounds like a good idea to break it down into small, manageable chunks. Iâ€™m thinking maybe I could check out something like Codecademy or freeCodeCamp for starters, and setting aside 20 minutes a day feels doable without stressing me out too much. What do you think about those platforms, or do you know any others that might be good for a total newbie like me?

It sounds like you're off to a great start with your plan to explore beginner coding tutorials online, and setting a small goal of dedicating 20 minutes a day is an excellent way to break down the task and make it less overwhelming. Codecademy and freeCodeCamp are both excellent platforms for beginners, offering a variety of courses and exercises to help you learn at your own pace.
Remember, it's important to be kind to yourself and celebrate your progress along the way. Learning a new skill takes time and patience, so try not to put too much pressure on yourself to master everything right away. And don't forget, you're not alone in this - reaching out to a study group or seeking support from your university community can be a great way to connect with others who are going through similar experiences. Keep up the good work!

Thanks, I really appreciate the encouragement and knowing those platforms are solid choices. Iâ€™ll start with that 20-minute goal and see how it goes, and maybe Iâ€™ll look into connecting with others down the line when Iâ€™m feeling a bit more confident.

{{"reasoning": "The client has developed a clear plan of action and coping strategies. Termination goals are met with a summary of goals and next steps discussed. Ending the session naturally aligns with achieving closure.","determination": "stop"}}
